author: thepunnman
body: Doesn’t matter if you buy at the top. The farthest out .7d nvda call costs roughly $6k. If you thetagang that and sell cc against that, which is roughly $100/week and you win 80% of the time, which means that you make money on your sold cc’s 41.6 weeks out of the 52 (rounded down to 41), you make back your initial investment in 75 weeks, or just the tiniest more than the lifetime of the leaps option. Even if your leaps eats shit and dies, you’re making money every week that makes up for it. This doesn’t even take into account if your leaps increases in value, and suddenly you’ve doubled your initial investment in a year

author: stonksrgud
body:
I buy as far out as available almost every time.  I buy at least 10% ITM. I do not sell calls on my leaps.  I hold them like shares.  I sell them 6mo before expiry.  I also consider selling as I just did with Googl msft and NVDA when a leap is up ~100%, and buy a higher strike.   

This is just my strategy.  Not advice for anyone else

author: UnstableCortex
body: I'm an electrical engineer, but not an expert on automobile engineering. But, I highly doubt if NVIDIA will be the beneficiary of the impending smart car boom. Smart cars will probably use more custom-made ASICs for intelligence than GPUs, as the latter is orders of magnitude less energy efficient than the former. And energy efficiency will be very important for battery powered smart cars.

author: PresterJohnsKingdom
body:
Hesitate to comment since it seems you're pretty combative with some of the other commenters, and I'm not looking for an argument. But here goes.

I think the basic principles of value investing are still alive and well, as long as you don't become shackled by rules (I won't buy a stock with a PE less than X or Y) and not adjust to the current dynamic.  

I don't think Ford or GM are good examples of a value play...for me, my "safe" money is in companies who I feel the market is undervaluing.  Exxon Mobile, Altria Group, etc. and a couple REITs.  These companies have simple products (oil, cigarettes) but have done nothing but make money for years, and return value to their stockholders in dividends. I'm

I still have a portion of my portfolio in growth, and haven't let high valuations scare me away from Nvidia, Cloudfare, Rocket Labs and other plays.

author: SirGasleak
body: You shouldn't make your decisions to buy based on the price of the stock by itself.  You need to dig deeper, look into some valuation metrics.  One thing to consider is that history has shown that stocks with high P/S ratios tend to underperform over time because that means the stock is already pricing in strong future growth.  As soon as that growth slows, the price takes a hit.  That's why you see so many high flying popular stocks selling off big on earnings these days.  With a P/S of 25, NVDA is up there - not crazy high, but up there.  That doesn't mean it is due for a selloff any time soon, but it does mean your upside from these levels is somewhat limited.

author: iopq
body:
Sorry to burst your bubble, but this company is a marketer of common components. Like they don't make their own power supplies, they have another company make it and they just paint it over with whatever color they like and slap the Corsair logo on it.

They make their own keyboards, but my wireless keyboard is shitty, after I charge it it stops working until I try turning it on and off again.

Are they going to make money? Yes. But they are basically cashing in on the brand image, not really putting out great products. They are in a commodity market where you can just buy a different brand and there will be no problem. I can't just buy something other than Nvidia - my CUDA code won't work. But I can buy any brand mouse, PSU, headphones, keyboard.

I'm not saying you won't make money with this stock - you will. But temper your expectations. This isn't gamestop that was shorted to near 0. This is a fairly valued company that will continue to do well and go up.

author: ENRONsOkayestAdvice
body:
I think people need to refresh or educate themselves on the differences between a shortage and a change in the demand curve.  And how this impacts prices.  Investors and traders need to ask themselves is the price going up because of inflation, or is the systemic change in demand due to lifestyle changes as a result of COVID?  If people can’t drink themselves silly at a bar, are they now buying cars, good equipment, computer games, and other things with money that would have been spent at the bar? 

Example “chip shortages”. Nothing mentioned in the $NVDA about a shortage, just excessive demand and not being able to keep up with production.  

Additionally, many companies have dug themselves into a hole and aren’t owning up to their mistake (automakers).  They cut production at the beginning of COVID and we are literally paying for their mistake by not being patient.  It’s also a fault of inventory management system like “Just In Time Inventory management (JTM) where it assumes the supply chain won’t have major interruptions in the supply chain.  I am sure several industries are going through the same pains.

author: GraysonMA
body:
When you buy leaps you are taking on a lot of vega exposure which can add significant risk to your portfolio. However, vega gives you a second way to win if you stick to companies that have IVR/IV% near their 52 week lows. [Barchart is a great resource for finding these.](https://www.barchart.com/options/iv-rank-percentile/stocks?orderBy=optionsWeightedImpliedVolatility&orderDir=asc)
I also choose underlyings that have low correlation with each other. This keeps things a little less volatile which is especially important using any type of leverage. [PortfolioVisualizer has a great tool for this.](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SPY+TLT+KO+PG+D+INTC+MCD+VZ+FB+MSFT+NVDA+LLY+NEE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36). Leaps I bought recently are in PG, INTC, FB, D, MSFT, KO, VZ, and MCD. LLY is an solid low correlation pick but I’m waiting for a dip in IV.
